Headline: DQ Page header.
Paragraphs: Within MSDN Page header is similar with a few different nuances depending on what it is being applied to but in regards to Template 10 it is talking about the Page header control. What it does is allow the developer the ability to create common page elements and uniform page UI (Nixon, 2016). Things that are covered by the Page header element include things like the header text and primary/secondary buttons. The key features include primary/secondary button commands, navigation, and style customization. It allows the developer the ability to create a consistent page header across the program. I do find it interesting that the back button isn’t enabled out of the box and has to be instead set to visible and bond to the frame, but it is a control that gives you a page header and menu template to build on.

Headline: DQ .Hamburger control.
Paragraphs: The Hamburger control (data model being realized by a control template) is basically the Hamburger menu from Template 10. It allows the developer the ability to create a hamburger menu-based navigation (Nixon, 2016). It will give the developer access to a navigation system with primary and secondary buttons, along with built in styles that are easily customizable. It also integrates well with the PageHeader control. One thing that I just noticed after watching the video is that the primary buttons are at the top ad the secondary buttons are at the bottom while I usually think of secondary buttons as the next layer under a primary button. I also found out that you can stack secondary buttons horizontally if the text is removed. Back to the Hamburger control, the styling includes HamburgerBackground (set background color), HamburgerForeground (sets forground, ie text color), NavAreaBackground (background brush of panel), NavButtonBackground (background color of highlighted button), NavButtonForeground (foreground color of highlighted button), and

SecondarySperator ) color of the separator between the primary and secondary buttons) (Nixon,2016). There is also a HamburgerMenu.IsFullScreen which basically makes the content full screen and suppresses the Hamburger Menu.

Headline: DQ Title bar
Paragraphs: The title bad control allows the developer the ability to customized the Title bar from within XAML code instead of calling an API (Nixon, 2016). The developer can change the background/foreground colors along with the color of the buttons along with taking the top of the content and moving it into the Title bar.

Headline: DQ Modal dialog
Paragraphs: The Modal dialog is a control that allows the developer the ability to display content ontop to the rest of the UI and blocks access to the elements beneath it (Nixon, 2016). For me it remindes me of opening a message box or form in model mode that basically will not let the user do anything except deal with that message or control.

Headline: DQ Resizer control
Paragraphs: Going by MSDN the resizer control is the control that allows the developer the ability to resize triangular objects by specifying the size and location of that object. It would be used in things like textboxes, buttons, images and allow the developer the ability to programmatically change its size and location within the form/page.
